# 英国早期青少年设计教育运动研究
#### ——以皇家艺术学院为中心的考察(1974-1995)


##### **时间**：2021 
##### **团队**：**刘蓝静**，张磊
##### **关键词**：设计史，青少年设计教育，设计研究

## 摘要
本文梳理了上世纪七十到八十年代英国皇家艺术学院对基础教育中设计教学审查、发展、推广的研究与实践工作，该工作极大推动设计进入了英国中小学课程体系。本文探究了：一，英国率先倡导实施设计基础教育的初衷和难点是什么;二，设计研究如何有效地推动了这场教育变革;三，怎样评价早期青少年设计教育运动的得失。

劝导式设计的FBM行为模型
提出了设计概念与成长计划，旨在帮助年轻女性克服错误的饮食观念、回归正常的生活方式。

# MORE & more #### 针对年轻女性「由节⻝减肥导致的暴⻝问题」的用户研究与设计 ##### **时间**：2021 ##### **团队**：**刘蓝静**，魏伊茗，郑茜月，张淳，刘希敏 ##### **关键词**：用户研究，产品服务系统设计 ## 设计说明 在信息爆炸时代很多年轻女性承担了更多的身材焦虑。为了达到理想的体型效果，有很多年轻女性选择通过严格限制饮食达到减重。但这种失调的饮食态度与饮食状况往往会导致她们在一段时间后出现暴食行为。在暴食时，她们通常感到失控、沮丧，在进食后甚至会生发出自我厌弃、抑郁等情绪。MORE&more针对这一现象进行了深入的用户调研，通过社交媒体的日记观察分析、一对一用户访谈形成年轻女性因节食而暴食的真实周期。根据前期的调研结果，我们基于[劝导式设计的FBM行为模型](https://doi.org/10.1145/1541948.1541999)提出了设计概念与成长计划，旨在帮助年轻女性克服错误的饮食观念、回归正常的生活方式。 ![moremore](/moremore/2.png)
图1：调研过程
![moremore](/moremore/3.png)
图2：调研结果：中国年轻女性真实的暴食周期

关键词单鞋交换为平等而设计服务设计

children.value: ：单鞋交换，为平等而设计，服务设计

世界上几乎所有的鞋品零售商都是成双成对地销售鞋子。这种销售模式忽视了独脚残疾人购买单只鞋的需求——他们不得不长年购买“一双鞋”。这不但造成另一只鞋在资源上的浪费，同时也加剧了独脚残疾人在经济上的困难，进一步造成社会对残疾人的不平等待遇。减少不平等是实现联合国可持续发展的目标之一，旨在呼吁对弱势和边缘群体的关怀和帮助。OneShoe由此出发，创建了一个面向独脚残疾人的单鞋置换与销售平台，使独脚残疾人之间能够交换闲置的鞋子。OneShoe使每只鞋的价值最大化的同时，消除了独脚残疾人必须购买一双鞋的不平等现象。

_data.text:
# OneShoe #### 独脚残疾人士的单鞋交换应用 ##### **时间**：2020-2021 ##### **团队**：张超，吴嘉贻，胡雅静，**刘蓝静** ##### **关键词**：单鞋交换，为平等而设计，服务设计 ##### **奖项**：2021 iF Talent Award ## 设计说明 世界上几乎所有的鞋品零售商都是成双成对地销售鞋子。这种销售模式忽视了独脚残疾人购买单只鞋的需求——他们不得不长年购买“一双鞋”。这不但造成另一只鞋在资源上的浪费，同时也加剧了独脚残疾人在经济上的困难，进一步造成社会对残疾人的不平等待遇。减少不平等是实现联合国可持续发展的目标之一，旨在呼吁对弱势和边缘群体的关怀和帮助。OneShoe由此出发，创建了一个面向独脚残疾人的单鞋置换与销售平台，使独脚残疾人之间能够交换闲置的鞋子。OneShoe使每只鞋的价值最大化的同时，消除了独脚残疾人必须购买一双鞋的不平等现象。 ![oneshoe](/oneshoe/2.jpg)

children.value: ：上海市青少年创意设计院，上海市科技艺术教育中心
地方意识是一个跨学科名词，指个人与一个地方、 空间划分的环境或地点的关系 [
]等词相接近。这些概念都表明了个人与地方之间关系的重要性，也伴随着各种模型。Eisenhauer认为地方意识受两方面影响：人——家庭和朋友之间的社交、相关活动和传统，以及与此相关的记忆；物理环境——自然景观、风景、气候、地质特征、环境设置和生物 [
]；Scannell和Gifford将地方依恋的因素确定为人（person）、地方（place）和进程（process） [
]；Domingues等人则构建了一个由地方、人、时间和自我构成地方意识的四方结构 [

]。
发展地方意识的重要性已经得到广泛认同 [
]，尤其是在儿童和青少年时期 [
]。发展儿童地方意识的工作通常会选择学校与社区作为起点，儿童在此建立了他们的友谊和与他人的联系，即他们的社会网络和社会资本 [
]。Severcan发现随着儿童参与更多的社区规划和设计活动，他们对邻里和社区的感情明显增加，这对于发展儿童的亲社会行为非常重要 [
]。Lucy Grimshaw和Lewis Mates论证了儿童学习城市地方历史和遗产的经验可以帮助发展他们的地方意识 [

]。
2020年以来，新冠疫情导致的封控措施使儿童与社区、地方的接触更加困难。Chris Pascal和Tony Bertram通过一项跨国定性研究显示，儿童希望恢复他们的日常生活，与他们的朋友在一起，有较长的游戏时间，在户外活动，并有真实信息 [
]。Russell Wendy认为在新冠流行后儿童应更多地参与到城市与社区的规划 [
]。并且，地方意识能够在一定程度上帮助儿童克服疫情以来的心理健康问题 [
]，Miranda等人认为家庭和社区的纽带和关系在疫情期间的心理健康结果中也发挥着重要作用 [
]。Adler-Kassner等人认为提供基于社区实践的课程不仅能够帮助学生发展地方意识还能够帮助他们更好的学习 [

]。
在经历了2022年新冠疫情导致的上海封控后，9名儿童参与了以社区为基础的设计工作坊，了解新冠疫情对他们地方意识的影响，并帮助他们加强对社区的认知、关联，发展地方意识。这个工作坊依托Domingues等人提出的地方意识模型 [

]，引导儿童关注社区中的人、地方、时间以及自我，鼓励儿童以此为基础发现社区中的问题并提出解决的思路和方案以发展他们的创造力和问题解决能力。工作坊为期十一天，儿童通过在线的方式参与（腾讯会议和飞书文档），活动流程和教学工具在工作坊中得到了发展、测试和迭代。在工作坊中，我们发现新冠疫情导致的封控使儿童更关注社区的工作人员，例如保安人员、医护人员和居委会工作人员等，儿童更多地认为自己是社区的一部分，但他们对其他居民的接触和认知极少；并且一些非常规的活动使他们对社区环境的规划和设计充满疑惑。在工作坊结束后，大部分儿童表示他们对自己的社区和社区中的人有了更深的了解和连接，并且提出了合理的社区环境与活动规划的设计方案。在这个项目中，工作坊的实施和教学工具作为重点介绍。
图1：工作坊流程设置介绍
图2：儿童进行设计原型制作
图3：儿童设计的作品与原型：（a）为社区的老人和儿童提供的休息平台；（b）社区河边的临时羽毛球场；（c）可伸缩的核酸检测车

# 野生空间大侦查 #### 新冠疫情后发展儿童地方意识的设计工作坊 ##### **时间**：2022.08-2022.09 ##### **团队**：**刘蓝静** ##### **关键词**：设计思维，地方意识，线上教学，设计工作坊，儿童， ##### **合作支持**：上海市青少年创意设计院，上海市科技艺术教育中心 ## 简介 地方意识是一个跨学科名词，指个人与一个地方、 空间划分的环境或地点的关系 [[7](https://doi.org/10.1068/b37054)]，通常与地方依恋 [[20](https://books.google.com.sg/books/about/Perceptual_and_Cognitive_Image_of_the_Ci.html?id=kAEqlbTaFDkC&redir_esc=y), [18](https://psycnet.apa.org/record/1992-37330-001), [16](https://doi.org/10.1080/00958960109598658)]、地方认同 [[6](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvp.2007.06.003)]等词相接近。这些概念都表明了个人与地方之间关系的重要性，也伴随着各种模型。Eisenhauer认为地方意识受两方面影响：人——家庭和朋友之间的社交、相关活动和传统，以及与此相关的记忆；物理环境——自然景观、风景、气候、地质特征、环境设置和生物 [[3](https://doi.org/10.1080/089419200403848)]；Scannell和Gifford将地方依恋的因素确定为人（person）、地方（place）和进程（process） [[13](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvp.2009.09.006)]；Domingues等人则构建了一个由地方、人、时间和自我构成地方意识的四方结构 [[4](https://www.jsod-cieo.net/journal/index.php/jsod/article/view/289)]。 发展地方意识的重要性已经得到广泛认同 [[2](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.emospa.2013.02.008), [11](https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=XHyxAAAAIAAJ&q=Place+and+Placelessness&dq=Place+and+Placelessness&hl=&sa=X&redir_esc=y), [15](https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=Ln2fQgAACAAJ&dq=Space+and+Place&hl=&sa=X&redir_esc=y)]，尤其是在儿童和青少年时期 [[7](https://doi.org/10.1068/b37054), [5](https://doi.org/10.1177/00420980211019597)]。发展儿童地方意识的工作通常会选择学校与社区作为起点，儿童在此建立了他们的友谊和与他人的联系，即他们的社会网络和社会资本 [[17](https://doi.org/10.1177/0042098008100998)]。Severcan发现随着儿童参与更多的社区规划和设计活动，他们对邻里和社区的感情明显增加，这对于发展儿童的亲社会行为非常重要 [[14](https://www.jstor.org/stable/44113116)]。Lucy Grimshaw和Lewis Mates论证了儿童学习城市地方历史和遗产的经验可以帮助发展他们的地方意识 [[5](https://doi.org/10.1177/00420980211019597)]。 2020年以来，新冠疫情导致的封控措施使儿童与社区、地方的接触更加困难。Chris Pascal和Tony Bertram通过一项跨国定性研究显示，儿童希望恢复他们的日常生活，与他们的朋友在一起，有较长的游戏时间，在户外活动，并有真实信息 [[10](https://doi.org/10.1080/1350293X.2021.1872676)]。Russell Wendy认为在新冠流行后儿童应更多地参与到城市与社区的规划 [[12](https://doi.org/10.1080/23748834.2020.1795386)]。并且，地方意识能够在一定程度上帮助儿童克服疫情以来的心理健康问题 [[19](https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2022.775624), [9](https://doi.org/10.1080/23748834.2020.1795385)]，Miranda等人认为家庭和社区的纽带和关系在疫情期间的心理健康结果中也发挥着重要作用 [[8](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijdrr.2020.101845)]。Adler-Kassner等人认为提供基于社区实践的课程不仅能够帮助学生发展地方意识还能够帮助他们更好的学习 [[1](https://doi.org/10.20343/teachlearninqu.10.34)]。 在经历了2022年新冠疫情导致的上海封控后，9名儿童参与了以社区为基础的设计工作坊，了解新冠疫情对他们地方意识的影响，并帮助他们加强对社区的认知、关联，发展地方意识。这个工作坊依托Domingues等人提出的地方意识模型 [[4](https://www.jsod-cieo.net/journal/index.php/jsod/article/view/289)]，引导儿童关注社区中的人、地方、时间以及自我，鼓励儿童以此为基础发现社区中的问题并提出解决的思路和方案以发展他们的创造力和问题解决能力。工作坊为期十一天，儿童通过在线的方式参与（腾讯会议和飞书文档），活动流程和教学工具在工作坊中得到了发展、测试和迭代。在工作坊中，我们发现新冠疫情导致的封控使儿童更关注社区的工作人员，例如保安人员、医护人员和居委会工作人员等，儿童更多地认为自己是社区的一部分，但他们对其他居民的接触和认知极少；并且一些非常规的活动使他们对社区环境的规划和设计充满疑惑。在工作坊结束后，大部分儿童表示他们对自己的社区和社区中的人有了更深的了解和连接，并且提出了合理的社区环境与活动规划的设计方案。在这个项目中，工作坊的实施和教学工具作为重点介绍。 ![designerofcommunity](/designerofcommunity/7.png)
图1：工作坊流程设置介绍
![designerofcommunity](/designerofcommunity/5.png)
图2：儿童进行设计原型制作
![designerofcommunity](/designerofcommunity/6.png)
图3：儿童设计的作品与原型：（a）为社区的老人和儿童提供的休息平台；（b）社区河边的临时羽毛球场；（c）可伸缩的核酸检测车

children.value: ：上海市青少年创意设计院，上海市科技艺术教育中心

同理心在沟通、协作和创造力的发展中起着关键的作用，而童年被视为发展这种认知能力的关键阶段。然而，目前发展儿童同理心的方法大多将他们与真实的世界隔离开来，未能将他们的情感和认知的同理心转化为帮助他人的实际意见和行为。我们进行了为期三个月的三轮行动研究，在行动研究中我们对儿童、教师和设计师进行了访谈、观察等形成性研究，我们认为教师的指导、教学工具的使用以及与现实世界的接触是支持儿童在设计教育活动中发展同理心的重要因素。
其中，我们在第二、第三轮行动研究中对教学工具进行了迭代与测试，我们着重介绍了DetectiveMap，一个基于卡片的同理心工具包，用于帮助儿童在设计活动中发展同理心，它由六套卡片组成，即人物和物品卡、任务卡和用户文档、问题目标、洞察地图、便签和设计卡。在第三轮行动研究中，我们对12名儿童进行了初步的用户研究以检验其有效性。研究结果表明，它成功地激发了儿童的同理心，并支持他们在现实世界中进行合作和行动。
图1：三轮行动研究的介绍
图2：第一次行动研究中对儿童进行访谈并记录上课的过程
图3：第二次行动研究中儿童在使用教学工具
图4：第三次行动研究中与儿童进行沟通
图6：（a）儿童在使用人物卡和物品卡；（b）儿童在任务卡的帮助下与社区中的人进行交谈；（c）儿童在使用问题目标；（d）儿童在使用洞察地图和设计卡
图7：儿童分析小时工的问题和要求，并为她设计的过程

数字孪生机场是运用数字孪生技术，克隆出与真实机场对应的虚拟系统，在虚拟系统中及时监控机场的每个角落并对机场运行进行把控与调配。智慧机场系统设计旨在解决机场内外存在的信息不透明、服务不连贯、缺乏信息互联等痛点和需求，为旅客、机场管理与工作人员和相关服务人员提供一体化的系统与服务设计。除了对机场流程与系统的优化外，智慧机场系统为多方人员提供了模块化、自适应的交互界面，能够根据实时情况及时展示相关信息。
图3：机场大屏管理端设计

children.value: ：腾讯互娱，罗布乐思，上海市青少年创意设计院，上海市科技艺术教育中心
游戏改变社区工作坊借助罗布乐思引导儿童思考社区规划、运用已有知识并不断产出新的想法来实现自己对社区的设计构想。
同学们在对真实社区改造案例
进行参观后通过头脑风暴将参观时感受到的问题与自己真实生活中遇到的问题联系、对比，提出、阐述自己对这些问题的看法，倾听其他同学对同一问题的不同的观点，并且以不同的角度和立场进行沟通和交流。除了身边的真实案例之外，课程还从全球视野出发，向同学们介绍纽约、波士顿、伦敦和巴黎等城市经典的社区改造案例。
同学们在罗布乐思中能够实现社区空间的拓展、视角的转换、 动态的变化、多角度的设计；利用特效呈现出动态的社区 ;在不同的状态下，社区也呈现出不同的功能以满足居民的生活。最后从不同的方面为大家解读自己的作品——从为什么要设计这样的社区开始，将自己设计构思社区的过程、实现的过程，以此培养他们的表达能力和相对完整的叙事沟通能力。
图1：工作坊过程：（a）同学们在讨论社区的规划；（b）儿童在绘制社区的规划意向；（c）同学们在展示设计的社区。
图2：同学们通过罗布乐思实现社区原型制作
图3：同学们的作品：（a）绿意盎然的未来生活实体；（b）自然保护和科技发展融为一体的社区设计；（c）以环境保护、技术和中国文化为主题的未来社区。

_data.text:
# 游戏改造社区 #### 通过游戏设计促进儿童和青少年参与到社区规划 ##### **时间**：2020.10-2020.12 ##### **团队**：罗布乐思授课团队，**刘蓝静** ##### **关键词**：数字素养，设计思维，城市规划，游戏设计 ##### **合作支持**：腾讯互娱，罗布乐思，上海市青少年创意设计院，上海市科技艺术教育中心 ## 简介 游戏改变社区工作坊借助罗布乐思引导儿童思考社区规划、运用已有知识并不断产出新的想法来实现自己对社区的设计构想。 同学们在对真实社区改造案例[“NICE2035未来生活原型街”](https://shdi.tongji.edu.cn/7f/35/c16427a163637/page.htm)进行参观后通过头脑风暴将参观时感受到的问题与自己真实生活中遇到的问题联系、对比，提出、阐述自己对这些问题的看法，倾听其他同学对同一问题的不同的观点，并且以不同的角度和立场进行沟通和交流。除了身边的真实案例之外，课程还从全球视野出发，向同学们介绍纽约、波士顿、伦敦和巴黎等城市经典的社区改造案例。 同学们在罗布乐思中能够实现社区空间的拓展、视角的转换、 动态的变化、多角度的设计；利用特效呈现出动态的社区 ;在不同的状态下，社区也呈现出不同的功能以满足居民的生活。最后从不同的方面为大家解读自己的作品——从为什么要设计这样的社区开始，将自己设计构思社区的过程、实现的过程，以此培养他们的表达能力和相对完整的叙事沟通能力。 ![virtualcommunity](/virtualcommunity/3.png)
图1：工作坊过程：（a）同学们在讨论社区的规划；（b）儿童在绘制社区的规划意向；（c）同学们在展示设计的社区。
![virtualcommunity](/virtualcommunity/4.png)
图2：同学们通过罗布乐思实现社区原型制作
![virtualcommunity](/virtualcommunity/5.png)
图3：同学们的作品：（a）绿意盎然的未来生活实体；（b）自然保护和科技发展融为一体的社区设计；（c）以环境保护、技术和中国文化为主题的未来社区。

An investigation centred on the Royal College of Arts (1974-1995)
: Design Education Movement, Design History, Design Research

This paper surveys the work of the Royal College of Art in the 1970s and 1980s in reviewing, developing and promoting design in general education, which contributed significantly to the introduction of design into the British primary and secondary school. We argue that design education for young people was born out of the need for reform in basic education, and that it is also in line with design research and is mutually reinforcing; its development requires a joint effort between design and pedagogy.

# A study of the design education movement in the UK
#### An investigation centred on the Royal College of Arts (1974-1995)

##### **TIME**: 2021  
##### **TEAM**: **Lanjing Liu**, Lei Zhang
##### **KEYWORD**: Design Education Movement, Design History, Design Research



## ABSTRACT
This paper surveys the work of the Royal College of Art in the 1970s and 1980s in reviewing, developing and promoting design in general education, which contributed significantly to the introduction of design into the British primary and secondary school. We argue that design education for young people was born out of the need for reform in basic education, and that it is also in line with design research and is mutually reinforcing; its development requires a joint effort between design and pedagogy.

_data.title: Designer of Community | LANJING LIU

children.value: A design workshop for developing children's sense of place after the Covid-19 epidemic
: Sense of Place, Design Thinking，Online Design Workshop, Children
: Shanghai Youth Institute of Design and Innovation, Shanghai Science and Technology Art Education Centre
Sense of Place is an interdisciplinary term that refers to an individual's relationship to a place, spatially delimited environment or location [
] and is often close to terms such as place attachment [

]. Each of these concepts indicates the importance of the relationship between individuals and places, and is accompanied by various models. Eisenhauer argues that the sense of place is influenced by two aspects: people - socialization among family and friends, related activities and traditions, and the memories associated with this; the physical environment - the natural landscapes, landscapes, climates, geological features, environmental settings and organisms [
]; Scannell and Gifford identify the factors of place attachment as people, place and process [
]; and Domingues et al. construct a quadripartite structure of the sense of place - person, time, self and process [
The importance of developing a sense of place has been widely recognised [

]. Efforts to develop children's sense of place often start from school and community, where children build their friendships and connections with others, i.e. their social networks and social capital [

]. Severcan found that as children engaged in more community planning and design activities, their attachment to their neighbourhoods and communities increased significantly, which is important for the development of pro-social behaviour in children [
]. Lucy Grimshaw and Lewis Mates argued that children's experiences of learning about urban local history and heritage can help develop their sense of place [

Since 2020, the covid-19 epidemic has led to lackdown that have made it more difficult for children to engage with their communities and places. Chris Pascal and Tony Bertram showed through a cross-national qualitative study that children want to resume their daily lives, be with their friends, have longer playtimes, be outdoors and have authentic information [
]. Russell Wendy argues that children should be more involved in urban and community planning after the epidemic [
]. And, a sense of place can go some way to helping children overcome mental health problems since the epidemic [
], and Miranda et al. argue that family and community bonds and relationships also play an important role in mental health outcomes during a pandemic [
]. Adler-Kassner et al. argue that providing a curriculum based on community practices can not only help students develop sense of place but also help them learn better [

After experiencing the lackdown caused by the 2022 epidemic in Shanghai, nine children participated in a community-based design workshop to understand the impact of the covid-19 epidemic on their sense of place, and to help them strengthen their knowledge, connections and develop a sense of place in their community. The workshop built on the model of place consciousness proposed by Domingues et al [

] and guided the children to focus on people, places, time and self in their communities, encouraging them to use this as a basis to identify problems in their communities and suggest ideas and solutions to develop their creativity and problem-solving skills. The workshops lasted eleven days and children participated online (through Tencent Meetings and Lark), with activity flows and teaching tools developed, tested and iterated upon during the workshops. During the workshop, we found that the lackdown due to the epidemic made the children more concerned about the community workers, such as security guards, health care workers and residents' committee workers, etc. The children perceived themselves more as part of the community, but they had very little contact and knowledge of other residents; and some unconventional activities made them confused about the planning and design of the community environment. At the end of the workshop, most of the children indicated that they had a deeper understanding and connection with their own community and the people in it, and came up with reasonable design solutions for community environment and activity planning. In this project, the workshop implementation and teaching tools are highlighted.

Figure3: Works and prototypes designed by children: (a) A rest platform for the elderly and children in the community; (b) A badminton court by a river in the community; (c) A scalable nucleic acid testing vehicle for community.

_data.text:
# Designer of Community #### A design workshop for developing children's sense of place after the Covid-19 epidemic ##### **TIME**: 2022.08-2022.09 ##### **TEAM**: **Lanjing Liu** ##### **KEYWORD**: Sense of Place, Design Thinking，Online Design Workshop, Children ##### **CO-SUPPORT**: Shanghai Youth Institute of Design and Innovation, Shanghai Science and Technology Art Education Centre ## PROJECT DESCRIPTION Sense of Place is an interdisciplinary term that refers to an individual's relationship to a place, spatially delimited environment or location [[7](https://doi.org/10.1068/b37054)] and is often close to terms such as place attachment [[20](https://books.google.com.sg/books/about/Perceptual_and_Cognitive_Image_of_the_Ci.html?id=kAEqlbTaFDkC&redir_esc=y), [18](https://psycnet.apa.org/record/1992-37330-001), [16](https://doi.org/10.1080/00958960109598658)] and place identity [[6](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvp.2007.06.003)]. Each of these concepts indicates the importance of the relationship between individuals and places, and is accompanied by various models. Eisenhauer argues that the sense of place is influenced by two aspects: people - socialization among family and friends, related activities and traditions, and the memories associated with this; the physical environment - the natural landscapes, landscapes, climates, geological features, environmental settings and organisms [[3](https://doi.org/10.1080/089419200403848)]; Scannell and Gifford identify the factors of place attachment as people, place and process [[13](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jenvp.2009.09.006)]; and Domingues et al. construct a quadripartite structure of the sense of place - person, time, self and process [[4](https://www.jsod-cieo.net/journal/index.php/jsod/article/view/289)]. The importance of developing a sense of place has been widely recognised [[2](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.emospa.2013.02.008), [11](https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=XHyxAAAAIAAJ&q=Place+and+Placelessness&dq=Place+and+Placelessness&hl=&sa=X&redir_esc=y), [15](https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=Ln2fQgAACAAJ&dq=Space+and+Place&hl=&sa=X&redir_esc=y)], particularly in childhood and adolescence [[7](https://doi.org/10.1068/b37054), [5](https://doi.org/10.1177/00420980211019597)]. Efforts to develop children's sense of place often start from school and community, where children build their friendships and connections with others, i.e. their social networks and social capital [[17](https://doi.org/10.1177/0042098008100998)]. Severcan found that as children engaged in more community planning and design activities, their attachment to their neighbourhoods and communities increased significantly, which is important for the development of pro-social behaviour in children [[14](https://www.jstor.org/stable/44113116)]. Lucy Grimshaw and Lewis Mates argued that children's experiences of learning about urban local history and heritage can help develop their sense of place [[5](https://doi.org/10.1177/00420980211019597)]. Since 2020, the covid-19 epidemic has led to lackdown that have made it more difficult for children to engage with their communities and places. Chris Pascal and Tony Bertram showed through a cross-national qualitative study that children want to resume their daily lives, be with their friends, have longer playtimes, be outdoors and have authentic information [[10](https://doi.org/10.1080/1350293X.2021.1872676)]. Russell Wendy argues that children should be more involved in urban and community planning after the epidemic [[12](https://doi.org/10.1080/23748834.2020.1795386)]. And, a sense of place can go some way to helping children overcome mental health problems since the epidemic [[19](https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2022.775624), [9](https://doi.org/10.1080/23748834.2020.1795385)], and Miranda et al. argue that family and community bonds and relationships also play an important role in mental health outcomes during a pandemic [[8](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijdrr.2020.101845)]. Adler-Kassner et al. argue that providing a curriculum based on community practices can not only help students develop sense of place but also help them learn better [[1](https://doi.org/10.20343/teachlearninqu.10.34)]. After experiencing the lackdown caused by the 2022 epidemic in Shanghai, nine children participated in a community-based design workshop to understand the impact of the covid-19 epidemic on their sense of place, and to help them strengthen their knowledge, connections and develop a sense of place in their community. The workshop built on the model of place consciousness proposed by Domingues et al [[4](https://www.jsod-cieo.net/journal/index.php/jsod/article/view/289)] and guided the children to focus on people, places, time and self in their communities, encouraging them to use this as a basis to identify problems in their communities and suggest ideas and solutions to develop their creativity and problem-solving skills. The workshops lasted eleven days and children participated online (through Tencent Meetings and Lark), with activity flows and teaching tools developed, tested and iterated upon during the workshops. During the workshop, we found that the lackdown due to the epidemic made the children more concerned about the community workers, such as security guards, health care workers and residents' committee workers, etc. The children perceived themselves more as part of the community, but they had very little contact and knowledge of other residents; and some unconventional activities made them confused about the planning and design of the community environment. At the end of the workshop, most of the children indicated that they had a deeper understanding and connection with their own community and the people in it, and came up with reasonable design solutions for community environment and activity planning. In this project, the workshop implementation and teaching tools are highlighted. ![designerofcommunity](/designerofcommunity/4.png)
Figure 1: The workshop process.
![designerofcommunity](/designerofcommunity/5.png)
Figure2: Children making prototype.
![designerofcommunity](/designerofcommunity/6.png)
Figure3: Works and prototypes designed by children: (a) A rest platform for the elderly and children in the community; (b) A badminton court by a river in the community; (c) A scalable nucleic acid testing vehicle for community.
#### The Teaching Tool: [Online View](https://www.figma.com/file/bNZEgbLL9KZw7DBgYQtWo4/%E9%87%8E%E7%94%9F%E7%A9%BA%E9%97%B4-%E5%9C%A8%E7%BA%BF%E7%89%88?node-id=0%3A1) #### The Syllabus: [Click for more information (Chinese Only)](https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/cx9B_IpKA87nB1V3E4B3EA)

_data.title: Detective in Community | LANJING LIU

children.value: A action research on promoting youth empathy through design thinking workshop
: Action Research, Teaching Tools, Empathy, Design Education, Children
: Shanghai Youth Institute of Design and Innovation, Shanghai Science and Technology Art Education Centre

Empathy plays a key factor in the development of communication, collaboration, and creativity, and childhood has been seen as a critical phase for developing this cognitive ability. However, current approaches to developing children's empathy isolate them from the real world, failing to translate their affective and cognitive empathy into practical opinions and behaviors of helping others. We conducted a three-cycle action research over four-month in which we conducted formative study including interviews and observations with children, educators and designers, and we identified teacher guidance, teaching tools and engagement with the real world as important factors in supporting children's development of empathy in design education activities.

We iterated and tested  the teaching tool in the second and third cycle, we highlighted the DetectiveMap, a card-based empathy toolkit for helping children develop empathy in design activities, consisting of six sets of cards, namely Character and Object Cards, Task Cards and User File, Problem Targets, Insight Map, Sticky Notes, and Design Card. In the third cycle, we conducted a preliminary user study with 12 children to examine the effectiveness. The results of the study showed that succeeded in motivating children's empathy and supporting them to collaborate and act in the real world.
Figure 1: The three cycles of our action research.
Figure 2: Interview with children and lessons record in the first cycle.
Figure 3: Children using the teaching tool in the second cycle.
Figure 4: Communicated with children in the third cycle.
Figure 6:  (a) Children using Character and Object Cards; (b) Children in community with Task Cards; (c) Children using Problem Targets; (d) Children using Insight Map and Design Card.
Figure 7: Process of children analyzing the problems and requirements of the hourly worker, and designing for her.

# Detective in the Community #### A action research on promoting youth empathy through design thinking workshop ##### **TIME**: 2021.05-2021.09 ##### **TEAM**: **Lanjing Liu**, Zhanhui Xu, Xiaoshan Wang ##### **KEYWORD**: Action Research, Teaching Tools, Empathy, Design Education, Children ##### **AWARD**: 2022 iF Talent Finalist ##### **CO-SUPPORT**: Shanghai Youth Institute of Design and Innovation, Shanghai Science and Technology Art Education Centre ## PROJECT DESCRIPTION Empathy plays a key factor in the development of communication, collaboration, and creativity, and childhood has been seen as a critical phase for developing this cognitive ability. However, current approaches to developing children's empathy isolate them from the real world, failing to translate their affective and cognitive empathy into practical opinions and behaviors of helping others. We conducted a three-cycle action research over four-month in which we conducted formative study including interviews and observations with children, educators and designers, and we identified teacher guidance, teaching tools and engagement with the real world as important factors in supporting children's development of empathy in design education activities. We iterated and tested the teaching tool in the second and third cycle, we highlighted the DetectiveMap, a card-based empathy toolkit for helping children develop empathy in design activities, consisting of six sets of cards, namely Character and Object Cards, Task Cards and User File, Problem Targets, Insight Map, Sticky Notes, and Design Card. In the third cycle, we conducted a preliminary user study with 12 children to examine the effectiveness. _data.title: OneShoe | LANJING LIU

children.value: A shoe exchange App for disabled people with one foot
: Chao Zhang, Jiayi Wu, Yajing Hu,
: Shoe Exchange, Design for Equality, Service Design

Almost every shoe retailer in the world sells shoes only in pairs. This retail practice ignores the needs of some disabled people to purchase a single shoe and represents an unequal and even discriminatory treatment of people with one foot. OneShoe is a single-shoe exchange platform created to eliminate this inequality. Thanks to OneShoe, people with one foot can exchange their unused shoes with others who have different foot disabilities. OneShoe eliminates the inequality of having to buy a pair of shoes while maximizing the value of every shoe.

_data.text:
# OneShoe #### A shoe exchange App for disabled people with one foot ##### **TIME**: 2020-2021 ##### **TEAM**: Chao Zhang, Jiayi Wu, Yajing Hu, **Lanjing Liu** ##### **KEYWORD**: Shoe Exchange, Design for Equality, Service Design ##### **AWARD**: 2021 iF Talent Award ## DESIGN DESCRIPTION Almost every shoe retailer in the world sells shoes only in pairs. This retail practice ignores the needs of some disabled people to purchase a single shoe and represents an unequal and even discriminatory treatment of people with one foot. OneShoe is a single-shoe exchange platform created to eliminate this inequality. Thanks to OneShoe, people with one foot can exchange their unused shoes with others who have different foot disabilities. OneShoe eliminates the inequality of having to buy a pair of shoes while maximizing the value of every shoe. ![oneshoe](/oneshoe/2.jpg)

_data.title: More & more | LANJING LIU

children.value: User research and design for young women with overeating caused by dieting
, Yiming Wei, Xiyue Zheng, Chun Zhang, Ximin Liu
: User Research, Product Service System Design, Persuasive Design

The information explosion has led to many young women taking on more body image anxiety. In order to achieve the desired body shape, many young women choose a strict dietary restriction. However, such disordered eating attitudes and eating conditions often lead to binge eating behaviour after a period of time. MORE&more, a user research and design innovation project, conducted in-depth user research on this phenomenon, using social media diary observations and one-on-one user interviews to develop a realistic picture of the cycle of binge eating among young women. Based on the results of the preliminary research, we developed a design concept and growth plan based on the
Fogg behavioural model of persuasive design
, aiming to help young women overcome their misconceptions about eating and return to a normal lifestyle.
Figure 2: Finding: The real binge cycle of Chinese young women.

_data.text:
# MORE & more #### User research and design for young women with overeating caused by dieting ##### **TIME**: 2021 ##### **TEAM**: **Lanjing Liu**, Yiming Wei, Xiyue Zheng, Chun Zhang, Ximin Liu ##### **KEYWORD**: User Research, Product Service System Design, Persuasive Design ## DESIGN DESCRIPTION The information explosion has led to many young women taking on more body image anxiety. In order to achieve the desired body shape, many young women choose a strict dietary restriction. However, such disordered eating attitudes and eating conditions often lead to binge eating behaviour after a period of time. MORE&more, a user research and design innovation project, conducted in-depth user research on this phenomenon, using social media diary observations and one-on-one user interviews to develop a realistic picture of the cycle of binge eating among young women. Based on the results of the preliminary research, we developed a design concept and growth plan based on the [Fogg behavioural model of persuasive design](https://doi.org/10.1145/1541948.1541999), aiming to help young women overcome their misconceptions about eating and return to a normal lifestyle. ![moremore](/moremore/5.png)
Figure 1: Research process.
![moremore](/moremore/6.png)
Figure 2: Finding: The real binge cycle of Chinese young women.

_data.title: Virtual Community | LANJING LIU

children.value: Integrating children and youth into community planning through game design
: Digital Literacy, Design Thinking, Game Base Learning(GBL), Urban Planning
: Tencent Entertainment, Roblox, Shanghai Youth Institute of Design and Innovation
Gamification design tools and design education for youth
The workshop used Roblox to guide children to think about community planning and generate new ideas built on existing knowledge to realise their own design ideas for their communities.
After a visit to the real-life community transformation case

, the students brainstormed and compared the problems they felt during the visit with the problems they encountered in their real lives, presented and explained their views on these problems, listened to other students' different views on the same problems, and communicate and exchange with different perspectives and positions. In addition to real-life examples from around the world, the course takes a global perspective and introduces students to classic examples of community transformation in cities such as New York, Boston, London and Paris.

By using Roblox, the students were able to expand the community space, shift perspectives, change dynamics and design from multiple perspectives; using special effects to present a dynamic community; and in different states, the community was presented with different functions to meet the life of the residents. At the end, they explained their work from different aspects - started from why they designed such a community, the process of designing and conceiving their own community, and the process of realising it - to develop their ability to express and communicate a relatively complete narrative.
Figure 1：Process of workshop：（a）Children discussing community planning;（b）Children drawing a community plan;（c）Children showing their plan of the future community.
Figure 2：Children building their future community in Roblox.

Figure 3：Design ideas of children: （a）A lush green future living entity;（b）A community where nature conservation and technological development coexist; （c）A community of the future with themes of environmental protection, technology and Chinese culture.

After a visit to the real-life community transformation case ['NICE 2035'](https://shdi.tongji.edu.cn/7f/35/c16427a163637/page.htm), the students brainstormed and compared the problems they felt during the visit with the problems they encountered in their real lives, presented and explained their views on these problems, listened to other students' different views on the same problems, and communicate and exchange with different perspectives and positions. In addition to real-life examples from around the world, the course takes a global perspective and introduces students to classic examples of community transformation in cities such as New York, Boston, London and Paris. By using Roblox, the students were able to expand the community space, shift perspectives, change dynamics and design from multiple perspectives; using special effects to present a dynamic community; and in different states, the community was presented with different functions to meet the life of the residents. At the end, they explained their work from different aspects - started from why they designed such a community, the process of designing and conceiving their own community, and the process of realising it - to develop their ability to express and communicate a relatively complete narrative. ![virtualcommunity](/virtualcommunity/3.png)
Figure 1：Process of workshop：（a）Children discussing community planning;（b）Children drawing a community plan;（c）Children showing their plan of the future community.
![virtualcommunity](/virtualcommunity/4.png)

![virtualcommunity](/virtualcommunity/5.png)
Figure 3：Design ideas of children: （a）A lush green future living entity;（b）A community where nature conservation and technological development coexist; （c）A community of the future with themes of environmental protection, technology and Chinese culture.

_data.title: Smart Airport | LANJING LIU

children.value: System design of the digital twin for integrated airport management
: Digital Twin, System Design, UI Design

A digital twin airport is a virtual system that uses digital twin technology to clone a real airport counterpart, in which every corner of the airport is monitored and controlled and deployed in time for airport operations. The smart airport system is designed to address the pain points and needs of opaque information, incoherent services and lack of information interconnection within and outside the airport, providing an integrated system and service design for passengers, airport management and staff and related service providers. In addition to the optimisation of airport processes and systems, the Smart Airport System provides a modular, adaptive interface for multiple parties to interact with each other and to display relevant information in a timely manner based on real-time conditions.

_data.text:

The smart airport system is designed to address the pain points and needs of opaque information, incoherent services and lack of information interconnection within and outside the airport, providing an integrated system and service design for passengers, airport management and staff and related service providers. In addition to the optimisation of airport processes and systems, the Smart Airport System provides a modular, adaptive interface for multiple parties to interact with each other and to display relevant information in a timely manner based on real-time conditions. ![smartairports](/smartairports/1.png)

_data.title: You and Me in Design | LANJING LIU

children.value: A design thinking course for youth to learn and experience the design process
: Design Thinking, Creative Making, Design, Children
: Shanghai Youth Institute of Design and Innovation
The design thinking course aimed to provide participants with an opportunity to experience, perceive and practice the relationship between designers and users in the design process.

During the design process, participants connected indirectly and directly with user objects as real designers. In this course, the design process was not confined to the classroom and the computer, but the students actually faced the user object and produce the product.
Communication with the user and the advancement of design through the production of prototypes was the focus of the course, which exploreed the question of "who is the designer for and design for whom".
Figure 1: Participants' design works:（a）A container for hanging brushes designed for myself; （b）A retractable container for vegetables for the grocery shopper.
Figure 2: Participants' design works:（a）A sterilisable container for stationery designed for myself;（b）A flower vase designed for mum to prevent cats from harming the flowers.
